newsitem.title: PERU: Santander sees Peru April yr-on-yr GDP up 13.7 pct.
newsitem.headline: Santander sees Peru April yr-on-yr GDP up 13.7 pct.

text.p: Santander Investment said Monday it estimated Peru's April year-on-year economic growth was 13.7 percent, compared with 2.1 percent in April last year.

The strong growth prediction for April's gross domestic product (GDP) was based on healthy figures already published in some sectors and "conversations with government sources", Santander said in a statement.
The government is set to announce the country's April GDP figure later this week.

The investment arm of Spain's Banco Santander added its April GDP figure would mean year-on-year growth for the first four months was between 5.5 percent and 6 percent, compared with 0.7 percent in the same period last year.
Officials at the National Institute of Statistics and Information (INEI) provided the comparative figures for 1996 growth.

Analysts at Credibolsa -- the brokerage of Peru's largest commercial bank Banco de Credito -- had forecast April growth at 6.4 percent. But an analyst at the firm said the figure would be revised upward.

The Peruvian economy grew 4.8 percent year-on-year in the first quarter, compared with a 0.6 percent year-on-year growth in the January to March period of 1996, according to the government's latest GDP figures.
GDP growth in March was 5.2 percent year over year, compared with a 0.9 percent contraction in March last year.
